descendants.content:
@SuperMoosie @ClimateNewsNow Sort of, but traditional white paint is mostly only reflective in the visible light range. This new paint is reflective into the ultraviolet and infrared ranges, meaning it rejects more of the energy from the sun.

Edit to add: anybody interested in this should look into structural color. Most things around us are the color they are because of pigment. Structural color is instead a texture so fine it bends light. Some gets absorbed, some gets redirected in unexpected directions, and some gets reflected, depending on the texture’s exact size, spacing, and so on. Blue morpho butterfly wings are that beautiful, iridescent blue because of structural color, not pigment.

Some time ago, people determined how to use this to make a ceramic with tuned reflectivity. It’s used in various window tints (both for structures and cars) to cause the window to reflect infrared light (and the heat it carries) while remaining visually transparent. This paint uses similar techniques plus wide-spectrum pigments.

descendants.content:
@ClimateNewsNow another low-tech solution for parked cars is to get one of those windshield reflectors. i have to leave my car in a boiling parking lot all day at work, and the reflector noticeably lowers the temperature. the AC doesn't have to work as hard to cool the cabin down again.

i also noticed a surprising improvement in fuel economy when i just reduced the AC by 0.5°C while driving. (i.e. i turned up the car's thermostat by 0.5 degrees.) there was negligible impact on comfort.
